questions.description:
In the given diagram, identify what is depicted by A, B and C :
Choose the correct option :

options.description: A-Air going from lungs, B-Ribs and sternum relaxed, C-Volume of thorax increased
A-Air entering lungs, B-Ribs and sternum relaxed, C-Volume of thorax increased
A-Air entering lungs, B-Ribs and sternum raised, C-Volume of thorax increased
A-Air going out from lungs, B-Ribs and sternum relaxed, C-Volume of thorax decreased

questions.description: In the given figure, identify the muscles involved in raising the rib cage :
The alveoli and their ducts constitute ______ of the respiratory system :

options.description: Both conducting as well as respiratory parts

questions.description: Trachea is internally lined by :
Mammalian lungs contain a large number of alveoli. This is to facilitate :

options.description: More space for increasing the total volume of inspired air
More surface area for diffusion of gases
More spongy texture for keeping lungs in proper shape
More nerve supply to keep the organs working more efficiently

questions.description: Total number of alveoli in both lungs of human is about :
The incomplete cartilagenous rings in trachea are example of :

Match the columns :
Column-I
a. Larynx
b. Trachea
c. Alveoli
d. Epiglottis
Column-II
i. Lid of larynx 
ii. Air sacs
iii. Voice box
iv. Wind pipe 
v. Common passage
In man and other mammals, air passes from outside into the lungs through :

options.description: Nasal cavity, larynx, pharynx, trachea, bronchi, alveoli
Nasal cavity, larynx, pharynx, trachea, bronchioles, alveoli
Nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchioles, bronchi, alveoli
Nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli

questions.description: Animals which have a network of tracheal tubes to transport atmospheric air within the body are :
Select the option that represents respiratory part of respiratory passage :
The nasal cavity serves all of the following functions, except :

options.description: As a passageway for air movement
As initiator of the cough reflex

questions.description: During swallowing, the entry of food in the trachea triggers a strong cough, forcing the food out of trachea immediately. Normally the entry of food in trachea is prevented by :
Which group of animals respire through lungs ?
Skin of man cannot act as respiratory organ because:

options.description: It is not permeable to O₂ and CO₂

questions.description: What is the function of respiratory part of human respiratory system ?

options.description: It clears the incoming air from foreign particles
It brings the temperature of air upto the body temperature
It exchanges O₂ and CO₂ between blood and atmospheric air

questions.description:
Read the following sentences carefully and select the correct option : 
 Statement A : The passage starting with the external nostrils upto the terminal bronchiole constitute the respiratory part. 
 Statement B : The respiratory part transport the air to the alveoli, clears it from the foreign material, humidifies and brings the air to body temperature.

options.description: Statement A is correct but statement B is incorrect
Statement B is correct but statement A is incorrect
Both statements A and B are correct
Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.description: Which of the following produces negative pressure in your thoracic cavity ?

options.description: Relaxation of the muscles between the ribs
Contraction of the muscles in the walls of stomach

questions.description: Inspiration can occur, when :

options.description: Pressure within the lungs is less than the atmospheric pressure
Pressure within the lungs is more than the atmospheric pressure
Pressure within the lungs and atmospheric air is same
No effect of pressure on inspiration

questions.description: By the contraction in diaphragm, volume of thoracic chamber increases in :
The total volume of air, a person can inspire forcefully after a normal expiration is :
Amount of air left in the lung after normal expiration is:
Minute Volume of Respiration (MVR) in a person can be defined as :

options.description: Breathing rate × (Tidal volume – Anatomical dead space)

questions.description: The primary muscle of inspiration is :
Total volume of air expired by a person forcefully after normal inspiration is known as :
Total volume of air, a person can expire after a normal inspiration ?
Which of the following statement is not true for man ?

options.description: Forceful expiration is an active process
Internal intercostal and abdominal muscles are muscles of forceful inspiration

questions.description: Functional residual capacity differs from residual volume in :

options.description: That it can never be exhaled totally
It can be measured by spirometer
Including one volume that can still be exhaled

questions.description: The TV + IRV + ERV is same as :
Which respiratory associated muscles would  be contracted if you blow up a balloon ?

options.description: Diaphragm contracts and internal intercostal muscles would relax
External intercostal muscle contract and phrenic muscles would contract
Internal intercostal and abdominal muscle would contract
Internal intercostal muscles and external intercostal muscles would contract

questions.description: Volume of thoracic chamber increases in anteroposterior and dorso-ventral axis in human by :

options.description: Contraction of diaphragm and external intercostal muscles respectively
Relaxation of diaphragm and external intercostal muscles respectively
Relaxation of diaphragm and abdominal muscles respectively
Contraction of abdominal muscles and relaxation of external intercostal muscles respectively

questions.description: An additional volume of air, a person can inspire by a forceful inspiration is known as :
Expiration occurs due to :

options.description: Relaxation of diaphragm and external intercostal muscles
Contraction of internal intercostal muscles and diaphragm
Relaxation of abdominal and internal intercostal muscles
Contraction of diaphragm and relaxation of abdominal muscles

questions.description: Volume of air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration is :
What happens to the volume of pulmonary cavity when there is an increase in the volume of thoracic chamber ?
Diaphragm is a dome-shaped muscular structure   which separates :
Tidal volume in human beings is :
What happens when pressure within the pulmonary    cavity is higher than the atmospheric pressure ?

options.description: No inhalation and expulsion of air occurs

questions.description: If a person exhales out forcefully by applying all his efforts. What will the pulmonary volume inhaled by him immediately under normal condition without applying any extra effort ?

Read the following sentences carefully and select the correct option : 
 Statement A : Normal expiration during quiet breathing, unlike inspiration, is a passive process because no muscular contractions are  involved. 
 Statement B : Normal expiration results from the elastic recoil of the chest wall and lungs.

options.description: Statement A is correct but statement B is incorrect
Statement B is correct but statement A is incorrect
Both statements A and B are correct
Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.description: What is the amount of air inspired or expired per minute, by a healthy human adult ?
Total lung capacity is the :

options.description: Volume of air that will remain in the lungs after a normal expiration
The maximum volume of air a person can breathe in after a forced expiration
Total volume of air a person can inspire after a normal expiration
Total volume of air accommodated in the lungs at the end of a forced inspiration

questions.description: Vital capacity of lung is equal to :
What is correct ?

options.description: Pulmonary ventilation is equal to alveolar ventilation
Alveolar ventilation is less than pulmonary ventilation
Alveolar ventilation is more than pulmonary ventilation

questions.description: If expiratory reserve volume is 1100 ml, residual volume is 1200 ml and tidal volume is 500 ml, what shall be the functional residual capacity ?
Binding of oxygen with haemoglobin is primarily related to pO₂. Which one of the following factors interferes with this binding ?
The factor favourable for the formation of oxyhaemoglobin is :
Which of the following conditions is the most appropriate for the dissociation of CO₂ from carbaminohaemoglobin ?
During transport of gases, movement of chloride ions from plasma to erythrocytes to maintain osmotic balance is known as :
Exchange of gases between blood and alveolar air takes place through :
What is the amount of oxygenated blood that can deliver about 5ml of O₂ to the tissues, under normal physiological conditions ?
Carbonic anhydrase is found in high concentration in :
O₂ and CO₂ are exchanged at the alveolar level by simple diffusion mainly due to the :
The blood leaving the lungs has its haemoglobin oxygenated and unloads its oxygen to the tissues,because :

options.description: The tissues can absorb O₂ from oxyhaemoglobin
O₂ concentration in tissues is lower and CO₂ concentration higher than that of lungs
O₂ concentration in tissues is higher and CO₂ concentration lower than that of lungs

questions.description: What would happen when blood is acidic ?

options.description: Affinity of oxygen with haemoglobin increases
Red blood corpuscles will be produced in greater number
Affinity of oxygen with haemoglobin decreases

questions.description: Chloride shift is required for transport of :
Which of the following factor can affect the rate of diffusion of gases ?

options.description: Thickness of the membranes involved in diffusion

questions.description:
Which of the following statement/s is/are correct ?
 a. A high concentration of carbonic anhydrase is present in RBC
 b. Minute quantities of carbonic anhydrase is present in plasma
 c. Every 100 ml blood delivers approximately 4 ml of CO₂ to the alveoli
 d. 20-25% CO₂ is carried by haemoglobin as carbaminohaemoglobin
To which part of Hb, CO₂ binds ?
Oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve will shift to right on decrease of :

Read the following sentences carefully and select the correct option : 
 Statement A : Major part of carbondioxide is transported in the form of sodium bicarbonate. 
 Statement B : 0.3 ml of carbon dioxide is transported per 100 ml of blood in dissolved state in plasma of blood.

options.description: Statement A is correct but statement B is incorrect
Statement B is correct but statement A is incorrect
Both statements A and B are correct
Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.description: The CO₂ content by volume, in the atmospheric air is about :
Which of the following can be termed as opposite of Bohr's effect ?
With which part of Hb, O₂ molecules bind ?
The carbon dioxide is transported via blood to lungs :

options.description: In the form of carbonic acid only

questions.description: How does the transport of O₂ and CO₂ by blood occur ?

options.description: With the help of WBCs and blood serum
With the help of platelets and corpuscles
With the help of RBCs and blood plasma
With the help of RBCs and WBCs

questions.description: With increase in body temperature due to enhanced metabolic activities in human body :

options.description: Oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve will shift to right side at tissue level
Affinity of haemoglobin for oxygen will increase at tissue level
Sensitivity of chemoreceptors to pO₂ increases dramatically while it falls for pCO₂ & H⁺

questions.description: Factor which is not favourable for the dissociation of HbO₂ in the body tissues is :
When percentage saturation of haemoglobin with O₂ is plotted against the partial pressure of O₂ on a graph, the curve obtained is described as :
The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in oxygenated blood is :

options.description: More than pO₂ in deoxygenated blood
Less than pCO₂ in atmospheric air

questions.description: Every 100 ml of deoxygenated blood delivers approximately ____ of CO₂ in the alveoli :
Which of the following factors cannot affect the binding of CO₂ with haemoglobin ?
The correct values of pCO₂ (in mm of Hg) in pulmonary veins and systemic veins is :
In Bohr's effect curve shift to right :

options.description: pCO₂ increases and pO₂ decreases and pH increases

questions.description: The diffusion rate of gases across alveolar membranes is :

options.description: Directly proportional to the thickness of diffusion membranes
Directly proportional to the solubility of gas being diffused
Inversely proportional to the thickness of diffusion membranes

questions.description: Increase in acidity has the same effect on oxygen dissociation curve as ____ has :
Select the correct statement w.r.t. transport of gases :

options.description: Haldane's effect is opposite to Bohr's effect
Hamburger's phenomenon is also called reverse chloride shift
About 20-25% of CO₂ is carried in carboxyhaemoglobin form
Approximately 4 ml of CO₂ is delivered by every 100 ml of oxygenated blood

questions.description: The maximum amount of carbon dioxide carried in blood is ___ as ___ :
Which among the given ones is the most probable reason for higher diffusion rate of CO₂ than O₂ through diffusion membrane, for per unit difference in partial pressure ?

options.description: More affinity of haemoglobin for O₂
Less pCO₂ difference in alveolar air and deoxygenated blood
Less than 1 mm thickness of diffusion membrane

questions.description: How much volume of oxygen will be delivered by 1 litre of oxygenated blood to the muscle performing strenuous work ?
Select the correct statement about oxygen transport in blood :

options.description: During normal activity, a molecule of haemoglobin returning to the lungs carries one molecule of oxygen
During acidosis, haemoglobin is able to carry oxygen more efficiently
Increased BPG levels in the red blood cell enhance oxygen carrying capacity of blood
Foetal haemoglobin has higher affinity for oxygen in comparison to maternal haemoglobin

questions.description:
Read the following sentences carefully and select the correct option : 
 Statement A : Diffusion of carbondioxide is 20 times faster than oxygen. 
 Statement B : It is due to difference in solubility of diffusing gases.

options.description: Statement A is correct but statement B is incorrect
Statement B is correct but statement A is incorrect
Both statements A and B are correct
Both statements A and B are incorrect

questions.description: Which are the three main layers that form the diffusion membrane ?

options.description: Thin squamous epithelium of alveoli, basement membrane of bronchioles and basement substance
Thin squamous epithelium of alveoli, endothelium of alveolar capillaries and the basement substance
Basement substance, cuboidal epithelium of alveoli and stratified epithelium of bronchiole
Ciliated epithelium of trachea, endothelium of capillaries and basement substance

questions.description: In lungs, the air is separated from the venous blood through :

options.description: Transitional epithelium of alveoli + squamous epithelium of blood vessel
Squamous epithelium of alveoli + cuboidal epithelium of blood vessel
Squamous epithelium of alveoli + squamous epithelium of blood vessel
Cuboidal epithelium of alveoli + columnar epithelium of blood vessel

questions.description: Respiratory centre of brain is stimulated by :

options.description: Carbon dioxide content in venous blood
Carbon dioxide content in the arterial blood
Oxygen content in the venous blood
Oxygen content in the arterial blood

questions.description: If a person living at sea level, migrates to 8000 feet high hill, his blood after about fifteen days will :

options.description: Have greater number of RBCs and more Hb

questions.description: Which part of the human brain controls the breathing movements ?
Emphysema is characterised by :
Which of the following is not occupational disease ?
Which of the following can alter respiratory mechanism ?
Less oxygen due to high levels of carbon dioxide is called :
Blood analysis of a patient reveals an unusually high quantity of carboxyhaemoglobin content. The patient has been inhaling polluted air containing unusually high content of :
Respiratory rhythm centre and pneumotaxic centre are respectively located in :
Peripheral chemoreceptors are located in :

options.description: Medulla oblongata, just adjacent to the respiratory rhythm centre

questions.description: Regarding the functions of conducting part of our respiratory system, mark the wrong entry :
A person suffers punctures in his chest cavity in an accident without any damage to the lungs. Its effect could be :
A person breathes in some volume of air by forced inspiration after having a forced expiration. This quantity of air taken in is :
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding respiratory system ?

options.description: Each terminal bronchiole gives rise to a network of bronchi
The lungs are covered by a double-layered membrane
The pleural fluid reduces friction on the lung surface

questions.description: Incidence of emphysema, a respiratory disorder is high in cigarette smokers. In such cases :

options.description: The alveolar walls are found damaged
The plasma membrane is found damaged
The respiratory muscles are found damaged

questions.description: In breathing movements, air volume can be estimated by :
